text:
Been spending the past few days up to my eyebrows learning about web3 and its ecosystem. Have you come across the HIVE blockchain and its various social front ends (e.g. PeakD, Ecency)?

Really fascinating stuff going on there. Learning curve is STEEP and pretty technical, especially to understand how single posts are netting over $100 each in crypto value... but it's happening.

Most interesting to me so far has been how the decentralized apps (dApps) work. I can take the value i earn on a social network (by both creating and curating), transfer it through an exchange and convert it into game currency to purchase a new card or box or whatever. It's easier if the game runs on same chain as the social network... but even if it doesn't there are ways to move the value.

It's all very primitive and NOT user friendly (well, if we're using Apple as a benchmark)... but the systems are being built and there is mondo cashola backing the innovation.

text: Oh interesting! No I haven't heard of the HIVE blockchain — do you have a rec for where I should start to learn about it?

elements.text: Oh interesting! No I haven't heard of the HIVE blockchain — do you have a rec for where I should start to learn about it?

text: <@U02BUAQA2JD> This article covers the high level bases and recommends some jumping off points: <https://wiki.rugdoc.io/docs/introduction-to-hive-blockchain/> :slightly_smiling_face:

attachments.fallback: RugDoc Wiki: Introduction To Hive Blockchain
attachments.text: Everything you need to know to get started with WEB 3.0 on the Hive blockchain.
attachments.title: Introduction To Hive Blockchain

elements.text: This article covers the high level bases and recommends some jumping off points:

text: Ah you rule, ty for sharing! :smile:

elements.text: Ah you rule, ty for sharing!

text: Also dApps sound kind of like gamified, unmoderated versions of a DAO...there are a few DAOs I've seen where users get crypto by completing bounties like creating and/or curating content (pubDAO, scribeDAO, etc.). Maybe that's a stretch to equate the two, but I see some similarities...

elements.text: Also dApps sound kind of like gamified, unmoderated versions of a DAO...there are a few DAOs I've seen where users get crypto by completing bounties like creating and/or curating content (pubDAO, scribeDAO, etc.). Maybe that's a stretch to equate the two, but I see some similarities...

text:
I'd say that's a fair comparison. From what I've gleaned, a dApp is basically anything that uses the blockchain as its database. Since the blockchain is public, anyone can build any dApp on top of it. PeakD and Ecency are great examples. If you log into one and post something, it'll show up on the other since they're both using the HIVE BC. They just present and organize the underlying info differently.

DAOs are technically dApps since they're built on some sorta chain, but have added characteristics like governance. So, based on my fledgling knowledge: all DAOs are dApps but not all dApps are DAOs :sweat_smile:

If you log into one and post something, it'll show up on the other since they're both using the HIVE BC. They just present and organize the underlying info differently.

DAOs are technically dApps since they're built on some sorta chain, but have added characteristics like governance. So, based on my fledgling knowledge: all DAOs are dApps but not all dApps are DAOs

text:
Most major dApps I've come across do have a governance component tho. Esp ones that run on chains with low/no fees.

Low/no fees = fewer nodes, and a community of stakeholders votes on who runs said nodes. To become a stakeholder, own some of the native token and literally stake it. Usually you earn interest on staking too, "dividends" determined by the governing body.
